summary: Happy Halloween from the Starks! Featuring:Robb as Captain AmericaJon as a very low effort Tony Stark (hey, he wanted to be a...
caption:
Happy Halloween from the Starks! Featuring:

Robb as Captain America

Jon as a very low effort Tony Stark (hey, he wanted to be a Stark for once…)

Sansa as Scarlet Witch

Arya as Black Widow

Bran as Hawkeye

and Rickon as Thor

summary:
The North will survive to the end because Sansa is at the helm. The rest of them? Eh, it’s a toss-up. 
Why? 
Well, simple, Sansa...
body:
The North will survive to the end because Sansa is at the helm. The rest of them? Eh, it’s a toss-up.

Why?

Well, simple, Sansa is shown worrying about logistics. She’s trying to make sure the North has enough food. She orders food to be stockpiled at Winterfell, because that’s where people are most likely to go during Winter. She suggest improvements to armor to keep their wearers warm, because wearing metal armor in below freezing temperatures will only kill you faster. She’s shoring up political alliances and getting all the Houses on these page because, as the Starks are prone to saying, in Winter, the lone wolf dies, but the pack survive.

We don’t see anyone else on this shows think about logistics. They’re all playing the messy game of strategy.

Examples of strategy (good or bad, I’ll leave that up to you) on this show include:

  • Daenerys burning the food train coming from High Garden (destroying a necessary food source that could have been saved for Winter)
  • Jon and crew going Beyond the Wall to capture a White Walker (a really risky move that put all of their lives in danger)
  • Daenerys taking all three of her dragons to save Jon and crew (resulting in the death of one of her dragons, which the Night King then revived to use as a weapon)
  • Daenerys taking her two remaining dragons to the Dragon Pit (inadvertently revealing that one may be dead; only bringing one would have made Cersei wonder where the other two are, rather than asking, “Hey, she’s got two dragons here. Where’s the third? Is it dead?”)
  • Cersei denying Daenerys the man power she had previously promised (thus sowing distrust between the two)

Look, there are other examples of strategy, good and bad, on this show. These are just the ones I could think of off the top of my head.

This might look a bit like I’m coming down hard on Daenerys here, but she did make a couple of strategic moves in season 7 that have some pretty bad consequences in the long run.

But, getting back to my point, playing strategy is all well and good when you’re on the battlefield in the heat of a battle. But in a war or in Winter? You need to think logistics. Any military leader would tell you that. Logistics wins wars and allow you to survive.

There’s a saying that I think sums this all up nice and simply - “Amateurs study strategy, but professionals study logistics.”

So, when Winter and the White Walkers come, having a solid food source, an enforced castle, and a supplied army/population will tip the odds in your favor. Everyone else will just be scrambling.

summary:
I ship neither Jon/Sansa nor Jon/Daenerys because ew. Jon is too closely related to both Sansa and Daenerys. 
If the showrunners...
body:
I ship neither Jon/Sansa nor Jon/Daenerys because ew. Jon is too closely related to both Sansa and Daenerys.

If the showrunners try to push either, I can and will be pissed AF.

If, God help us, the showrunners attempt to push Sansa and Daenerys as romantic rivals for Jon’s affection, I’m calling massive bullshit on the showrunners for doing that.

blog.name: acourtofhopeanddreams
blog.title: Enjoy the little things!
blog.description:
Open your heart
To the love of the world
It only needs one person
Touching it with 
A word
A look
A smile
A kiss

tags: Day 3: The stranger - the wrath - Alternate Universe
title: The Unknown
body:
Written for @jonsa-week Day 3: The Stranger

Jon won the war, but lost everything else. He’s the only one left standing. At least. He think he is.

It’s a post-canon (for now) and there is not that much Sansa in there, but JonSa is endgame ;-) Descriptions of a battlefield after battle where everyone died, apart from Jon.

Silence. Deafening Silence.

Jon barely dared to breath when the calm after the storm, the peace after the war, had finally arrived.

And he was still standing.

He was bruised all over his body. Blood seeped from countless wounds covering his skin. His armor was shredded and his hair a tangled mess. He was covered in sweat and dirt.

But he was still standing.

He seemed to be the only one.

Friends and foes laid in the muddy mixture of melting snow and smoking ashes. They had their eyes wide open and stared at the sky, where the winter clouds were chased away by the promise of spring.

They had won the war and lost it at the same time.

He had won the war and lost it at the same time.

His footsteps echoed all around him when he started walking. He tried to avoid the corpses and unrecognizable bodies as much as he could, but once in a while he stepped on a hand or foot, twisted in some weird angle.

If he could, he would close all their eyes and carry them home to the wives waiting for them, to the children hoping their fathers would come home, to their mothers praying day and night for a safe return of their children. But it were too many. Too many corpses to carry home, too many widows, too many children without a father, too many mothers without their sons.

But he was still standing.

His heart was still beating in his chest. His lungs were still breathing in the smoked and poisoned air. His eyes saw the destruction, the price they all paid for their freedom and safety.

In between the bodies of humans, lay the bodies of dragons. Once they had been fierce and strong. They had breathed fire and ice. They were responsible for most of the corpses, for most of the dead foes and friends. And in the end they had killed each other with the only weapon that could destroy them. The fire had killed the ice and the ice had killed the fire.

But he was still standing.

He had no sword anymore. At some point he had lost it, continuing the fight with his bare hands until the bitter end. Once the sword had been valuable and important, a weapon he would never leave behind. Now he hoped he would never need it anymore. He didn’t want to use it anymore. He never wanted to fight anymore. He had seen too much. He had done too much. He had escaped death a few too many times.

Not again. Never again.

He put one foot in front of the other. He climbed over piles of dead bodies without daring to look if he’d recognize them. For miles and miles he seemed to be the only soul alive.

No one else breathed. No one else moved. No one else stood. No one else walked. King slayers, dragon daughters, king mothers. Titles didn’t matter anymore. Status didn’t matter anymore. Those who fought, died. And dead they all looked alike. Miserable. Lonely. Broken. Empty.

But he was still standing.

He didn’t know what kept him going, apart from his beating heart pumping blood through his veins, apart from his stubborn lungs breathing in and out.

Nothing was waiting for him anymore. No one was waiting for him anymore. Those who mattered had come with him. Those who mattered had all died.

Apart from him. He was still standing.

He was still breathing. His heart was still beating. But he felt nothing anymore. He felt hollow and empty. He felt like nothing but a shell of whoever he had once been.

But he kept on walking, kept on climbing. And with each step it was easier to forget that the bodies he climbed over, the hands and feet he stepped on, had belonged to people he hated and loved. And with each step it was easier to forget that he had been their commander, that he had asked them to fight, that he had lead them to their very end.

Sam, Theon, Bran, Arya and Sansa. Most of all Sansa.

He fell down on his knees in the melting snow. He shouldn’t have brought them. He shouldn’t have brought her. If they’d not been here, if she’d not been here, he had someone left to live for, someone left to go home to.

He wanted to cry. He wanted to free his salted tears and let them roll down his cheeks. But he couldn’t. He was too tired, he was too hopeless, he was too broken.

He was surrounded by dead, surrounded by war, surrounded by the ugly leftovers of war. And there was nothing left for him apart from the great unknown. No future. No plans. No life.

He wanted to push himself up, but he couldn’t. He wanted to keep on walking, but he couldn’t. The war wasn’t ready to let go and there was nothing pulling him home.

“Jon…”

Jon’s eyes flashed open when he heard her voice. He was imagining it. He had to be imagining it.

He was the only one left standing.

“Jon…”

He saw the slight trembling of fingers, a few inches away from his own hands and on his knees he shoved towards her.

Her dress had been a bright green once, but now it was wrinkled, shredded and almost black. Her red hair was blooded and sweated.

But when his hand touched her wrist he could feel it.

Her heart was still beating. Her chest was moving up and dawn. Weakly and barely visible, but still.

Maybe not just cockroaches and weeds survived the odds.

“Sansa!” He lifted her body up and pressed her to his chest. His heart beat faster, pumping blood and adrenaline through his veins. “I’m gonna bring you home…”

“I know…” She didn’t open her eyes when he lifted her up.

And he didn’t have to force himself anymore to set one foot in front of the other, to climb over bodies of horses and men, to reach the edge of the battlefield and the beginning of their new life. “How did you know it was me?” He whispered while he kept on climbing and walking. “How did you know I survived?” He started running. Faster and faster, over the wasteland towards the green meadows.

“I felt it.” She spoke softly, but her lips curled up into a smile. “I always feel it when you’re near.”

Jon finally felt the tears rolling down her cheeks. Relief, sadness, anger, love, fear and the strangest kind of joy filled his numb and empty heart.

“I’m gonna get you home, Sansa.” He kissed her lips, her cheeks, her chin, her nose. “I’m gonna get you home.”

And whatever would wait for them there, they’d survive. Because the war was finally over.

And they were still standing.

No one else breathed. No one else moved. No one else stood. No one else walked. King slayers, dragon daughters, king mothers. Titles didn’t matter anymore. Status didn’t matter anymore. Those who fought, died. And dead they all looked alike. Miserable. Lonely. Broken. Empty.

But he was still standing.

He didn’t know what kept him going, apart from his beating heart pumping blood through his veins, apart from his stubborn lungs breathing in and out.

Nothing was waiting for him anymore. No one was waiting for him anymore. Those who mattered had come with him. Those who mattered had all died.

Apart from him. He was still standing.

He was still breathing. His heart was still beating. But he felt nothing anymore. He felt hollow and empty. He felt like nothing but a shell of whoever he had once been.

But he kept on walking, kept on climbing. And with each step it was easier to forget that the bodies he climbed over, the hands and feet he stepped on, had belonged to people he hated and loved. And with each step it was easier to forget that he had been their commander, that he had asked them to fight, that he had lead them to their very end.

Sam, Theon, Bran, Arya and Sansa. Most of all Sansa.

He fell down on his knees in the melting snow. He shouldn’t have brought them. He shouldn’t have brought her. If they’d not been here, if she’d not been here, he had someone left to live for, someone left to go home to.

He wanted to cry. He wanted to free his salted tears and let them roll down his cheeks. But he couldn’t. He was too tired, he was too hopeless, he was too broken.

He was surrounded by dead, surrounded by war, surrounded by the ugly leftovers of war. And there was nothing left for him apart from the great unknown. No future. No plans. No life.

He wanted to push himself up, but he couldn’t. He wanted to keep on walking, but he couldn’t. The war wasn’t ready to let go and there was nothing pulling him home.

“Jon…”

Jon’s eyes flashed open when he heard her voice. He was imagining it. He had to be imagining it.

He was the only one left standing.

“Jon…”

He saw the slight trembling of fingers, a few inches away from his own hands and on his knees he shoved towards her.

Her dress had been a bright green once, but now it was wrinkled, shredded and almost black. Her red hair was blooded and sweated.

But when his hand touched her wrist he could feel it.

Her heart was still beating. Her chest was moving up and dawn. Weakly and barely visible, but still.

Maybe not just cockroaches and weeds survived the odds.

“Sansa!” He lifted her body up and pressed her to his chest. His heart beat faster, pumping blood and adrenaline through his veins. “I’m gonna bring you home…”

“I know…” She didn’t open her eyes when he lifted her up.

And he didn’t have to force himself anymore to set one foot in front of the other, to climb over bodies of horses and men, to reach the edge of the battlefield and the beginning of their new life. “How did you know it was me?” He whispered while he kept on climbing and walking. “How did you know I survived?” He started running. Faster and faster, over the wasteland towards the green meadows.

“I felt it.” She spoke softly, but her lips curled up into a smile. “I always feel it when you’re near.”

Jon finally felt the tears rolling down her cheeks. Relief, sadness, anger, love, fear and the strangest kind of joy filled his numb and empty heart.

“I’m gonna get you home, Sansa.” He kissed her lips, her cheeks, her chin, her nose. “I’m gonna get you home.”

And whatever would wait for them there, they’d survive. Because the war was finally over.

And they were still standing.
trail.content:
Written for @jonsa-week Day 3: The Stranger

Jon won the war, but lost everything else. He’s the only one left standing. At least. He think he is.

It’s a post-canon (for now) and there is not that much Sansa in there, but JonSa is endgame ;-) Descriptions of a battlefield after battle where everyone died, apart from Jon.

Silence. Deafening Silence.

Jon barely dared to breath when the calm after the storm, the peace after the war, had finally arrived.

And he was still standing.

He was bruised all over his body. Blood seeped from countless wounds covering his skin. His armor was shredded and his hair a tangled mess. He was covered in sweat and dirt.

But he was still standing.

He seemed to be the only one.

Friends and foes laid in the muddy mixture of melting snow and smoking ashes. They had their eyes wide open and stared at the sky, where the winter clouds were chased away by the promise of spring.

They had won the war and lost it at the same time.

He had won the war and lost it at the same time.

His footsteps echoed all around him when he started walking. He tried to avoid the corpses and unrecognizable bodies as much as he could, but once in a while he stepped on a hand or foot, twisted in some weird angle.

If he could, he would close all their eyes and carry them home to the wives waiting for them, to the children hoping their fathers would come home, to their mothers praying day and night for a safe return of their children. But it were too many. Too many corpses to carry home, too many widows, too many children without a father, too many mothers without their sons.

But he was still standing.

His heart was still beating in his chest. His lungs were still breathing in the smoked and poisoned air. His eyes saw the destruction, the price they all paid for their freedom and safety.

In between the bodies of humans, lay the bodies of dragons. Once they had been fierce and strong. They had breathed fire and ice. They were responsible for most of the corpses, for most of the dead foes and friends. And in the end they had killed each other with the only weapon that could destroy them. The fire had killed the ice and the ice had killed the fire.

But he was still standing.

He had no sword anymore. At some point he had lost it, continuing the fight with his bare hands until the bitter end. Once the sword had been valuable and important, a weapon he would never leave behind. Now he hoped he would never need it anymore. He didn’t want to use it anymore. He never wanted to fight anymore. He had seen too much. He had done too much. He had escaped death a few too many times.

Not again. Never again.

He put one foot in front of the other. He climbed over piles of dead bodies without daring to look if he’d recognize them. For miles and miles he seemed to be the only soul alive.

No one else breathed. No one else moved. No one else stood. No one else walked. King slayers, dragon daughters, king mothers. Titles didn’t matter anymore. Status didn’t matter anymore. Those who fought, died. And dead they all looked alike. Miserable. Lonely. Broken. Empty.

But he was still standing.

He didn’t know what kept him going, apart from his beating heart pumping blood through his veins, apart from his stubborn lungs breathing in and out.

Nothing was waiting for him anymore. No one was waiting for him anymore. Those who mattered had come with him. Those who mattered had all died.

Apart from him. He was still standing.

He was still breathing. His heart was still beating. But he felt nothing anymore. He felt hollow and empty. He felt like nothing but a shell of whoever he had once been.

But he kept on walking, kept on climbing. And with each step it was easier to forget that the bodies he climbed over, the hands and feet he stepped on, had belonged to people he hated and loved. And with each step it was easier to forget that he had been their commander, that he had asked them to fight, that he had lead them to their very end.

Sam, Theon, Bran, Arya and Sansa. Most of all Sansa.

He fell down on his knees in the melting snow. He shouldn’t have brought them. He shouldn’t have brought her. If they’d not been here, if she’d not been here, he had someone left to live for, someone left to go home to.

He wanted to cry. He wanted to free his salted tears and let them roll down his cheeks. But he couldn’t. He was too tired, he was too hopeless, he was too broken.

He was surrounded by dead, surrounded by war, surrounded by the ugly leftovers of war. And there was nothing left for him apart from the great unknown. No future. No plans. No life.

He wanted to push himself up, but he couldn’t. He wanted to keep on walking, but he couldn’t. The war wasn’t ready to let go and there was nothing pulling him home.

“Jon…”

Jon’s eyes flashed open when he heard her voice. He was imagining it. He had to be imagining it.

He was the only one left standing.

“Jon…”

He saw the slight trembling of fingers, a few inches away from his own hands and on his knees he shoved towards her.

Her dress had been a bright green once, but now it was wrinkled, shredded and almost black. Her red hair was blooded and sweated.

But when his hand touched her wrist he could feel it.

Her heart was still beating. Her chest was moving up and dawn. Weakly and barely visible, but still.

Maybe not just cockroaches and weeds survived the odds.

“Sansa!” He lifted her body up and pressed her to his chest. His heart beat faster, pumping blood and adrenaline through his veins. “I’m gonna bring you home…”

“I know…” She didn’t open her eyes when he lifted her up.

And he didn’t have to force himself anymore to set one foot in front of the other, to climb over bodies of horses and men, to reach the edge of the battlefield and the beginning of their new life. “How did you know it was me?” He whispered while he kept on climbing and walking. “How did you know I survived?” He started running. Faster and faster, over the wasteland towards the green meadows.

“I felt it.” She spoke softly, but her lips curled up into a smile. “I always feel it when you’re near.”

Jon finally felt the tears rolling down her cheeks. Relief, sadness, anger, love, fear and the strangest kind of joy filled his numb and empty heart.

“I’m gonna get you home, Sansa.” He kissed her lips, her cheeks, her chin, her nose. “I’m gonna get you home.”

And whatever would wait for them there, they’d survive. Because the war was finally over.

And they were still standing.
trail.content_abstract:
Written for @jonsa-week Day 3: The Stranger

Jon won the war, but lost everything else. He’s the only one left standing. At least. He think he is.

It’s a post-canon (for now) and there is not that much Sansa in there, but JonSa is endgame ;-) Descriptions of a battlefield after battle where everyone died, apart from Jon.

Silence. Deafening Silence.

Jon barely dared to breath when the calm after the storm, the peace after the war, had finally arrived.

And he was still standing.

He was bruised all over his body. Blood seeped from countless wounds covering his skin. His armor was shredded and his hair a tangled mess. He was covered in sweat and dirt.

But he was still standing.

He seemed to be the only one.

Friends and foes laid in the muddy mixture of melting snow and smoking ashes. They had their eyes wide open and stared at the sky, where the winter clouds were chased away by the promise of spring.

They had won the war and lost it at the same time.

He had won the war and lost it at the same time.

His footsteps echoed all around him when he started walking. He tried to avoid the corpses and unrecognizable bodies as much as he could, but once in a while he stepped on a hand or foot, twisted in some weird angle.

If he could, he would close all their eyes and carry them home to the wives waiting for them, to the children hoping their fathers would come home, to their mothers praying day and night for a safe return of their children. But it were too many. Too many corpses to carry home, too many widows, too many children without a father, too many mothers without their sons.

But he was still standing.

summary: I have my issues with Season 7, but I love love love Sansa’s dark grey fur-lined cloak. It looks so snug, and it’s especially...
body:
I have my issues with Season 7, but I love love love Sansa’s dark grey fur-lined cloak. It looks so snug, and it’s especially stylish when she wears it over one shoulder.

and far more weather-fitting than that flimsy blue cloak she was still wearing in season 5 and 6 ffs

summary: do you think jonsa will be canon in the books
question: do you think jonsa will be canon in the books
answer:
my answer 2 years ago would have been a strong no. since then i’ve read book metas by jonsas and they have convinced me that the possibility is there. the thing that stands in the way is jon’s survival. grrm said people resurrected by red priests/priestesses are fire wights and considering the fact that the dragons and the others are going to die, it makes sense to me that fire wights will die too. 

if jon survives though, i think there’s a chance it will happen.

if jon survives though, i think there’s a chance it will happen.

summary:
I don’t get people who claim “He’s even uglier than the Hound” as an argument for Sansa/Hound because:
• That’s literally Sansa
body:
Some interesting connections

@fortunatelylori wrote an excellent reply to my post on Sansa’s nightmare that got me thinking about Sansa’s association of Sandor and Tyrion, and how they traumatised her. Here are three times when Sandor and Tyrion are explicitly connected:

“She dreamed of her wedding night with Tyrion, of Tyrion’s eyes devouring her as she undressed. Only he was bigger than Tyrion had any right to be, and when he climbed into bed his face was scarred only on one side. “I’ll have a song from you,” he rasped…“

(This is during her wedding to Tyrion) "He leant forward, and their lips touched briefly. He is so ugly, Sansa thought when his face was close to hers. He is even uglier than the Hound” ( @lostlittlesatellites wrote a meta on this line: http://lostlittlesatellites.tumblr.com/post/173705083127/i-dont-get-people-who-claim-hes-even-uglier)

http://lostlittlesatellites.tumblr.com/post/173705083127/i-dont-get-people-who-claim-hes-even-uglier

“She thought of Tyrion, and of the Hound and how he’d kissed her"

There are also dialogue parallels (“look at me” “open your eyes”) (if anyone has any others could you send them in?)

Sansa pities them both (which is more than they deserve), and they blame her for being shallow, for not wanting them. As @fortunatelylori put it: “they dehumanise her completely and see only a pretty face that rejects them and they end up hating her for it, and wanting her all the more. It’s sick and disgusting, not romantic”.

Fortunatelylori’s reply: https://fortunatelylori.tumblr.com/post/179553662496/i-just-had-a-really-disturbing-thought#notes

https://fortunatelylori.tumblr.com/post/179553662496/i-just-had-a-really-disturbing-thought#notes

reblog.comment:
Some interesting connections

@fortunatelylori wrote an excellent reply to my post on Sansa’s nightmare that got me thinking about Sansa’s association of Sandor and Tyrion, and how they traumatised her. Here are three times when Sandor and Tyrion are explicitly connected:

“She dreamed of her wedding night with Tyrion, of Tyrion’s eyes devouring her as she undressed. Only he was bigger than Tyrion had any right to be, and when he climbed into bed his face was scarred only on one side. “I’ll have a song from you,” he rasped…“

(This is during her wedding to Tyrion) "He leant forward, and their lips touched briefly. He is so ugly, Sansa thought when his face was close to hers. He is even uglier than the Hound” ( @lostlittlesatellites wrote a meta on this line: http://lostlittlesatellites.tumblr.com/post/173705083127/i-dont-get-people-who-claim-hes-even-uglier)

http://lostlittlesatellites.tumblr.com/post/173705083127/i-dont-get-people-who-claim-hes-even-uglier

“She thought of Tyrion, and of the Hound and how he’d kissed her"

There are also dialogue parallels (“look at me” “open your eyes”) (if anyone has any others could you send them in?)

Sansa pities them both (which is more than they deserve), and they blame her for being shallow, for not wanting them. As @fortunatelylori put it: “they dehumanise her completely and see only a pretty face that rejects them and they end up hating her for it, and wanting her all the more. It’s sick and disgusting, not romantic”.

Fortunatelylori’s reply: https://fortunatelylori.tumblr.com/post/179553662496/i-just-had-a-really-disturbing-thought#notes

https://fortunatelylori.tumblr.com/post/179553662496/i-just-had-a-really-disturbing-thought#notes

title: Hayrides and Hard Questions
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2JrzjAv

by Aryas_aria

Our favorite couple go to a fall festival. It should be the perfect date, so why is everything so complicated? Gift 1 of 2 for @arimonts23 for the Jonrya Spooky Secret Pumpkin!
